St, James's Park,1 z" ' London, S.W. 1,and the following number quoted./MINISTRY OF SHIPPING,as2-Bnd September, 1917.Sir,In continuation of my letter of the 17th Instant, I am directed by the Shipping Controller to report, for the information of the War Cabinet, as follows:-CONVOYS.(a) Homeward Bound Convoys. 51 convoys, consisting of 777 ships (5,370,600 tons deadweight) have been brought In up to date, and 15 convoys of 237 ships are on passage horns. Since the last report there has been the following casualty by enemy action -.-out of H.M.S. "ALBANY" convoy, the "IDOMENEUS" was torpedoed,but is still afloat. There have been no casualties by marine peri(b) Outward bound Convoys. 32 convoys of 457 shlos (2,992,000 tons deadweight) have been escorted through the danger' zone. The following casualties in convoy by enemy action have been reported'- the s.s."TUSCAPORA" was damaged and brought into Plymouth and the s,s."CMT0" damaged and brought into Queens town. The s.3."lNCHM00R" and the s.s."TUPY" were damaged by collision and both brought into port for repair.FINANCE.During the week ended the 15th instant payments amounting to 643,500 were made for compensation for total loss in the case of requisitioned ships, making a total of 19,029,522 paid since 1st April.I am,Sir,Your obedient Servant,ECRETAHY, CABINET.(Sad.) GRAEME THOMSON.
